head.title: Petition of the Inhabitants of Finsbury

ab.hi:
To ye righte honorable the Lordes and others
of her maiesties most honorable privie Councell:/

div.ab: In all humbleness: Wee the Inhabitantes of ye Lordshipp of. ffynisburye. within the parrishe of St Gyles without Creplegate London) Doe certifie vnto your honnours. That wheare the Servantes of the right honorable Earle of Nottingham. haue latelie gone aboute to erect and sett vpp. a Newe Playehowse. within the said Lordship) Wee could be contented, that the same might proceede, and be Tollerated (Soe it stande with your honnours pleasures) ffor the reasons and Causes followeinge/.

list.item: First because the Place. appoynted oute for that purpose Standent very tollerable neere vnto the ffeildes, and soe farr distant and remote frome any person or Place of accompt. As that None cann be Annoyed thearbie:/

Secondlie because the Erectours of the saied howse, are contented to give a very liberall porcion of money weekelie, towardes ye relief of our Poore, The nomber &amp;amp;amp; necesseity whereof, is soe greate that the same will redounde to ye contynuall comfort of ye saied Poore:

item.hi: Thirdlie and Lastlie wee are the rather Contented to accept this meanes of relief of our Poore, because our Parrishe is not able to releeue them. Neither hath the Iustices of the Sheire taken any order, for any Supplie oute of ye Countye, As is enioyed by ye late Acte of Parliamente:/

head.title: Letter from Joan Alleyn to Edward Alleyn

div.ab: My Intyre & welbeloved sweete harte still it Ioyes me & longe I pray god may I Ioye to heare of your healthe & welfare as you of ours Allmighty god be thancked my owne selfe your selfe, & my mother & whole house are in good healthe & about vs the sycknes Dothe Cease & likely more & more by godes healpe to Cease. All the Companyes be Come hoame & well for ought we knowe, but that Browne of the Boares head is Dead & Dyed very pore, he went not into the Countrye at all. and all of your owne Company ar well at theyr owne houses. my father is at the Corte but wheare the Court ys I known not…

After our harty. : 35mm lost due to tear to your Wher as the kings maiesties Plaiers have given tye : 30mm lost due to tearighnes good service in the Quallitie of Playinge and for as much Lickewise as they are att times to be emploied in that Service whensoever they shalbe Comaunded we thinke it therfore fitt (the time of Lent being now Past) that your Lordship doe Permitt and suffer the three Companies of Plaiers to the King Queene and Prince publicklie to exercise ther Plaies in ther severall and vsuall howses for that Purpose and noe other vz. The Globe scituate in maiden Lane on the Banckside in the Cowntie of Surrey the fortun in Goldinge Lane, and the Curtaine In Hollywelle in the Cowntie of Midlesex without any lett or Interupption In respect of any former Lettres of Prohibition heertofore written by vs to your Lordship. Except ther shall happen weeklie to die of the Plague Aboue the Number of thirtie within the Cittie of London and the Libertees therof. Att which time we thinke it fitt they shall Cease and forbeare any urther Publicklie to Playe vntill the Sicknes be againe decreaced to the saide Number, and so we bid your Lordship hartilie farewell ffrom the Court f at whitehalle the ixth of Aprille 1604

Your very Loving ffrends

head.title: Letter of Rev. William Norris and his Wife, Elizabeth, to Edward Alleyn

div.ab: Mr allane as unaquanted wee commend vs vnto yow, etc. wheras wee are credably enformed that you hould Certen Landes att London wherof the one halfe is due to our Children and the halfe of the rent is due vnto vs duringe the Lyfe of my wyffe asas: swritten over another letter it may appeere by our evidences; wee are therfore to desyre yow to doe so muche for vs as to paye our halfe rent into the handes of our Cozin mr patricke brewe, whome wee have auctorized to receave and to geue acquittance for the same and further wee request you nott to delyver our said. rent into the handes of no. maner person or persons but to vs or our Lawful attourney: for wee are not willing to receave our rent att the handes of noe man ells but from yourselfe, who doith hould the Land by our Leassee, and if our said rent should passe your handes and from hande to hande wherby wee or our Children may Come to trouble for our h owne:owne: ow written over other letters and smudged itt may bee an occation for vs to put those Landes with their evidences, into their handes that will deale more stricklier then wee meane or Intende to do: butt if you please to deale well with vs and to delyver our rentes to our attourneys, if the Children bee at any tyme willinge to so sell or sett to anie manne, you may have an offer before any other, the bearer herof Cann Certifye you how that Lande standeth. and for your better vnderstandinge/. we haue sent to you a Copie of an awarde ordered for the Children Concerning those Landes/ and thus hopinge you will accomplishe this our requestes wee Commit you to godes tuition from douglas in the Isle of manne this first of Iune in Anno Domini, 1608/

div.ab: This letter concerns a dispute which had arisen amongst the Gill family as to who was entitled to receive the ground-rent of the Fortune playhouse. William Noreis or Norris, was Vicar-General of the Isle of Man and had married Elizabeth, the widow of Daniel Gill the younger (J.Payne Collier, The Alleyn Papers (London, Shakespeare Society, 1843), 17-18 and 34-35). Patrick Brewe wrote several letters to Alleyn in 1609 concerning his acquisition of the freehold. In August Brewe informed him that Mrs Norris had died, and that her husband should now receive the ground-rent, and in December that the daughters of Elizabeth Norris were now prepared to sell their share of the site of the Fortune, for which John Garrett, holder of the reversion of the lease of the playhouse, had offered £300 (DCL: MS I.53–5). An earlier letter dated 12 January 1592/3 from the Revd. William Crowe of the Isle of Man, to Mr Patrick Brewe, citizen and goldsmith of London, also relates in some way to the ground on which the Fortune was built, although the playhouse is not mentioned by name, and to the ground-rents due to the grandchildren of ‘ould Gyll’ (DCL: MS III.7). Patrick Brewe was the man to whom Alleyn gave £240 for the lease of the property in 1599 (DCL: Muniment 20).

div.ab: Similar deeds were entered into by William Clark of the parish of Jourbie, Isle of Man, yeoman, and Elizabeth his wife, for £30, with £10 and then £20 due on the two next feasts of SS Phillip and James (1 May) next ensuing; Hugh Cannell, vicar of Kirk Michell, Isle of Man, and Jane his wife, for £40, due in equal instalments on the feasts of Sts Phillip and James, and on the Purification of the Blessed Virgin Mary (2 February) next ensuing; and Donald Qualtroughe of the parish of Kirk Loman, Isle of Man, yeoman, and Margaret his wife, £30, with £10 and then £20 due on the two next feasts of SS Phillip and James; the said Elizabeth, Jane and Margaret also being daughters of Daniel Gill, deceased (DCL: MS I.59-62). Earlier that month, Sir Jeremy Turnour had been given instructions as to the legal requirements to be carried out in the Isle of Man to convey the Fortune to Edward Alleyn, together with directions for the Commissioners there as to the procedures for the acknowledgement of the Fine for Edward Alleyn (DCL: MS I.56 and 57).

div.ab:
Sirthere is one Ihon Russell, that by your apoyntment was made a gatherer with vs, but my fellowes findingfinding: for finding him often falce to vs, haue many tymes warnd him from th taking the box And he as often, with moste Damnable othes, hath vowde neuer to touch, yet not withstanding his execerable othes, he hath taken the box & many tymes moste vnconsionablye gatherd, for which we haue resolud he shall neuer more come to the doore yet for your sake, he shall haue his wages, to be a necessary atendaunt on the stage, and if he will pleasure himself and vs, to mend our garmentes, when he hath leisure, weele pay him for that to, I pray send vs word if this motion, will satisfye you; for him his Dishonestye is such we knowe it will not,
Thus yealding ourselues in that & a farr greater matter to be comaunded by you I committ you to god

Your loving
ffrend to comaund
W. Birde

According to that power Edward Allein by deed Quadripartite dated 13o Septembris 17o Iacobi1619 did erect the Colledge to consist as thereby is appointed./

And by Indenture dated 24oApril 18o Iacobi24o 18oIacobi: 1620 Covenanted with William Alleine and William Austen that Edward before the feast day of St Iohn Baptist then next should acknowledge a fine vnto William Alleine and William Austen and their heirs of the mannour of Dulwich or ffortune Play house and other the messuages in that Indenture particularly specifyed to the vse of Edward Allein during his lyfe without impeachment of wast and after to the vse of the Incorporacion In which last Indenture is provisoe for Edward Allein to grant any lese or leases by Indenture or otherwise for soe many years or liues as he should thinke fitt reserueing rents therevppon intending the same after his death for the benefitt of the Incorporacion The fine was leuied and other Conveyances were made to William Alleine & William Austen accordingly:/

Whereas in and by a paire of Indentures bearinge date with these presentes made betweene the maister warden ffellowes Brothers sisters & schollers of Goddes guift in dulwich in the Countie of Surrey on the one parte and Tobias Lisle grocer on the other parte of a parte & an half parte in twelue partes to be devided of the ffortune playhowse betweene whitecrostreet & Golding lane in the county of Middlesex there is mencion made of ffiftye five powndes six shillinges and ten to be payd to the said Colledge for areeare of rent. Now it is declared by all vs whose names are subscribed that in regard mr Lisle did content vnto the said Colledge the summe of 50 li. in present payment, (the Colledge havinge agreed formerly to give long since of payment for the whole) therefore the said Colledge did abate 5 li. 6 s. 10 d. & did accept only of the said 50 li. witnes our handes this 22th of Iuly 1639.
Tobias Lisle continued to accumulate arrears of rent, over which the College initiated a legal suit between 1645 and 1649 (DCL: MS I.121 and 122).

div.ab: The humble peticion of Mathias Alleyn ye Master Thomas Alleyn the warden .4. ffellowes .6. poore brethren .6. poore sisters & 12. poore schollers of the Colledge called Gods Guift Colledge, in Dulwich founded by Edward Alleyn esquire, deceased.
Humbly sheweth

That your petitioners did heretofore exhibitt their Bill of complaint in this honorable Court against the Tennauntes of the ffortune Playhowse for rent which they unjustly detayned from your petitioners vpon pretence of a restraint from playing
That vpon a full hearinge of the said cause the 26th of Ianuary in the 14. yeare of our gracious King Charles1638/9 his Lordship did order that the said Tennaunts should pay all their rent in arreare without any abatement which accordingly they did either compound for and pay for a certaine tyme.

That since the making of the said order, one Iohn Beale bought a lease of a parte of the said Playhouse which lease was heretofore demised by the aforesaid Edward Alleyn to Edward Iacson vnder the yearely rent of 10 li. 13 s. 10 d., for which rent the said Beale is now in arreare 42 li. 15 s. 1 d.

That the said Iohn Beale combining with the rest of the tennaunts & have detayned their rent from the Colledge, whereupon your petitioners did exhibitt their [bill of complaint the second time in this honorable Court in Michalmas terme, in the 15th yeare of our gracious King Charles1639 and the Tennaunts being served with subpenas, to answer to the said bill, euery of the said tennaunts except the said Iohn Beale, pretended payment of their rent & did pay, but since doe detaine their rent to the great preiudice of the poore people of the said Colledge.
That the said Iohn Beale did delay your petitioners in putting in his Answer, insomuch that three Attachmentes issued out against the said Beale before he would put in his answer.

That the said bill & answer haueing had their due proceeding in this Court & publicacion being now past this hillary terme & the said tennaunts are runn in arreare with your petitioners the summe of 104 li.14 s.5 d. due at Christmas last past, insomuch that your petititoners to maintaine their poore of the said Colledge, are compelled to take moneys at interest to supply their wants. Now in tender consideracion of your petitioners greate necessity herein.

Your petitioners humbly pray your honour to bee pleased according to the aforesaid order hereunto annexed that all the tennaunts which are behinde with their rent, may be ordered to pay their rentes to the Colledge, or otherwise to bee pleased to set downe a day of hearing the said cause sometime this vacacion before your honour, that your petitioners may not bee delayed any longer by the said Iohn Beale and the rest of the aforesaid tenauntes. All which your petitioners doth submitt to your honours graue wisdome and charitable consideracion. And shall pray for your happines, &c.
The abouesaid order of 26 of Ianuary and the Certificate for Publicacion are hereunto annexed.

ab.add: If this cause be ready for hearing, lett it be sett Downe for the fourth seale after the Terme, so as proces be timely served on the adverse parties.

div.ab: The tenants of the Fortune playhouse had again fallen into arrears with their annual rent, and it appears that the Fortune was no longer profitable. In Hilary term 1640 the College initiated a bill in Chancery against John Beale to compel the payment of the rent due on his lease and for repairs. Beale made answer in 1641, where he described the Fortune playhouse as being in ‘Whitecross Streete in Golding lane London’ (DCL:MS I.119). The interrogatories and depositions on behalf of Beale are in TNA/PRO: C24/663/11. However, before 1640 it appears the company had moved to the Red Bull at Clerkenwell (J.Payne Collier, The Alleyn Papers (London, Shakespeare Society, 1843), 96–8.

Iohannem Churchill

Further litigation over arrears of rent at the Fortune continued from 1646 to 1649 (DCL: MSS I.121(1-13), 122 (1-11) and 123).
